course_title: Occupational Therapy for Children & Youth I for Graduates

learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate professional skills including the ability to evaluate learning and work collaboratively to develop effective client-centred and interprofessional practice.

Describe and apply acquisitional, sensory processing, psychosocial, and bio-mechanical frames of reference as they relate to improving the occupational performance and participation of children and youth with various developmental and learning conditions within occupation-centred and family-centred practice.
Apply information gathering skills and assess aspects of occupational performance through observation and activity analysis.

Demonstrate the ability to work collaboratively with peers to analyse, assess and communicate relevant aspects of occupational performance demonstrating an understanding of child development and cultural expectations.
Demonstrate the ability to interpret and apply the outcomes obtained during the information gathering process to develop appropriate client-centered goals.

Demonstrate the ability to identify the best available evidence from multiple sources to appropriately apply frames of reference when planning occupation and family-centred therapy activities/strategies.
Demonstrate the ability to apply strategies for communicating effectively with peers, children, and parents/caregivers, including therapeutic use of self.

Demonstrate the ability to apply interprofessional practice skills to work collaboratively with other professionals for optimal client outcomes, including defining the role of occupational therapy within paediatrics.
Demonstrate the ability to communicate outcomes of assessment of occupational performance to relevant stakeholders using professional language and expression appropriate to the audience.

assessments.task_description:
This assignment is completed in pairs. Students will be required to write a professional report based on their interpretation of information gained through the discussions with their client's parent/caregiver, their client's PE teacher (student), their child client, as well as their own clinical observations.


To complete this assessment, students will be involved in the Motor Active Program conducted through the School of Human Movement and Nutrition Sciences. Students will attend a fieldwork activity involving an interprofessional practice experience aimed at developing skills in supporting children within schools. Attendance within these sessions is compulsory and will contribute to your overall placement hours. Further details regarding the assignment can be found with the task description provided via Learn.UQ.


Extensions can be requested for this assessment item. Please apply for an extension request via my.UQ > my.UQ Dashboard > my. Requests  and provide evidence of circumstance, as soon as it becomes evident that an extension is needed, but no later than the assessment item submission date. Further information regarding what constitutes an acceptable reason for an extension is listed on the my.UQ website: Applying for an extension - my.UQ - University of Queensland


Generative AI (ChatGPT) - This assessment task evaluates student's abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Report to be submitted via Turnitin link. Due date 17th April 2pm.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment will be completed individually. Drawing from the knowledge gained from the completion of assessment task 1, students will be required to develop an intervention/strategy to support their child's participation within the Motor Active Program. This intervention/strategy, will be implemented by the PE teaching students, and therefore, students will be required to reflect on the OT role within schools, and strategies to support positive interprofessional practice. Further details regarding the assignment can be found with the task description provided via Learn.UQ.


Extensions can be requested for this assessment item. Please apply for an extension request via my.UQ > my.UQ Dashboard > my. Requests  and provide evidence of circumstance, as soon as it becomes evident that an extension is needed, but no later than the assessment item submission date. Further information regarding what constitutes an acceptable reason for an extension is listed on the my.UQ website: Applying for an extension - my.UQ - University of Queensland


Generative AI (ChatGPT) - This assessment task evaluates student's abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of Artificial Intelligence (AI). Students are advised that the use of AI technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submission of electronic files via Learn.UQ. Due date 23rd May 2pm
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Viva Exam - Case Assignment Clinical Encounter
assessments.task_description:
Assessment task 3 will involve a 20 minute on-line oral discussion/clinical encounter with a clinical educator playing the role of your child client's PE teacher. This discussion will be based around the intervention/strategy you developed in Assessment task 2 and how you plan to support the child's teacher to implement this activity within Motor Active.


Deferred exams can be requested for this assessment item. Please apply for a deferred exam if there are exceptional or unavoidable circumstances, or as a one-off discretionary request. Deferred exam requests should be submitted as soon as possible, and no later than five calendar days after the date of the original exam. Further details, including how to apply, can be found at - Deferring an exam. Please also email the Course Coordinator to advise of the deferred exam request.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Motor Active Program

This learning activity involves interprofessional practice, where you will collaborate with 2nd-year Physical Education students from the School of Human Movement and Nutrition Sciences (HMNS). Throughout Semester 1, Physical Education students manage a program called Motor Active, designed to enhance physical literacy among children and young people with disabilities. Participation within this learning activity is compulsory for completion of your assessment items.
learning_activities.topic_description: Motor Active Program This learning activity involves interprofessional practice, where you will collaborate with 2nd-year Physical Education students from the School of Human Movement and Nutrition Sciences (HMNS). Throughout Semester 1, Physical Education students manage a program called Motor Active, designed to enhance physical literacy among children and young people with disabilities. Participation within this learning activity is compulsory for completion of your assessment items.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

Each week lectures will address two areas of practice relevant to working with children, adolescents and families. These include:

1) Occupational therapy models of practice, frames of reference, interventions and contexts, and;

2) A range of developmental, attentional and learning conditions impacting on children's occupational performance and participation.

Lectures are planned to be delivered live on-line, however will also be recorded to support student learning.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

Tutorials provide additional learning materials and opportunities for practical application to support the lectures delivered each week. These are designed to develop skills required to meet professional competency standards. Tutorial content will be delivered face to face through both guided and self-directed activities. Please note that tutorials will not be recorded if you are unable to attend a tutorial it is your responsibility to speak with a peer to ensure you are up to date on all necessary course content.
